sub_title: Doctor of Engineering (Dr.-Ing.) | Postdoctoral Research Associate @VU
summary:
Driven by a passion for creating practical and impactful solutions, I am a multidisciplinary professional with a focus on adaptive policy-making and systems change. With a PhD in Safety Engineering, a Master's in Applied Geoinformatics for Environmental and Risk Management, and a Bachelor's in Marine Sciences, I bring a unique blend of expertise in crisis, emergency and disaster risk management, applied geoinformatics, spatial data science, crisis informatics, environmental management and sustainability. I have a strong focus on building resilience and ensuring safety and security for communities, assets, and infrastructures. 

Currently, I am exploring the potential of social media and crowdsourcing in enhancing disaster resilience via crisis communication strategies as part of my work with VU and the LINKS EU Project. 

"Someone has to see closer to realise the bigger picture because details hide the solution to complex problems".
#resilience #crisis #emergency #disaster #response #risk #management  #complexadaptivesystems #climatechange #sustainability #spatialanalysis #volunteeredgeographicinformation #socialmedia #geographicinformationsystems #systemschange #innovation

projects.title: LINKS “Strengthening links between technologies and society for European disaster resilience”
projects.description:
LINKS “Strengthening links between technologies and society for European disaster resilience” is a comprehensive study on disaster governance in Europe. The overall aim of the LINKS project is to strengthen links between technologies and society for improved European disaster resilience, by producing sustainable advanced learning on the use of social media and crowdsourcing (SMCS) in disasters.

In order to reach the core objectives of LINKS, the partners follow an integrative research approach, starting from an assessment of the three complementary knowledge domains: Disaster Risk Perception and Vulnerability, Disaster Management Processes, Disaster Community Technologies (DCT).

The project will develop the LINKS Framework which consists of scientific methods, practical tools, and guidelines addressing researchers, practitioners, and policy makers to understand, measure and govern SMCS for disasters. It will be developed and evaluated through five practitioner-driven European cases representing different disaster scenarios in Denmark, Germany, Italy, and the Netherlands. Furthermore, LINKS sets out to create the LINKS Community, which brings together a wide variety of stakeholders, both online (LINKS Community Center) and in person (LINKS Community Workshops).

contributors.headline: Doctor of Engineering (Dr.-Ing.) | Postdoctoral Research Associate @VU

projects.title: KIRMin – Kritische Infrastruktur-Resilienz als Mindestversorgungskonzept” (CIRMin – Critical Infrastructures Resilience as a Minimum Supply Concept)
projects.description:
How does a blackout impact on water supply systems and how can their complete breakdown be avoided? These questions are in the focus of the research project "KIRMin" (CIRMin) which has started in June 2016.
The research project "KIRMin – Kritische Infrastruktur-Resilienz als Mindestversorgungskonzept” (CIRMin – Critical Infrastructures Resilience as a Minimum Supply Concept) is funded in the context of the research program "Zivile Sicherheit – Erhöhung der Resilienz im Krisen- und Katastrophenfall" by the Federal Ministry of Education and Research (BMBF).

Consortium Lead: Prof. Alexander Fekete

WP III Lead: Katerina Tzavella

projects.title: BigWa: Interdisciplinary Key Research Area Civil Protection under Societal Change
projects.description: Aim: through interdisciplinary cooperation between the four disciplines Applied Social Sciences, Rescue Engineering, Communication Sciences and Information Technology/Communication Technology it is possible to differentiate the connections between societal change and civil protection in their entire complexity. This interdisciplinary research approach enables an innovative change in perspective.

projects.title: MC Impulse
projects.description:
EU FP7 Marie Curie Initial Training Network
MC Impulse (Monte Carlo based Innovative Management and Processing for an Unrivaled Leap in Sensor Exploitation) is an Initial Training Network, focusing on research and training in the field of sensor data processing.

Focus
The research program focuses on the development of novel methods for real-time signal and data processing, based on data collected form sensors or networks of sensors. MC IMPULSE is expected to generate specific innovations such as:
- Advanced methods for detecting and tracking objects by processing information from (a network of) sensors
- New methods and algorithms for information fusion from multiple sensors and their efficient processing for on-line applications. 

One of the key techniques that is focused on is Sequential Monte Carlo or Particle Filtering. MC IMPULSE joins different scientific disciplines such as: electrical engineering, communication theory, estimation theory, signal processing and detection theory, mathematics and physics.

- Participated in the process for a DIN SPEC 91390:2019-12 developed in the project: Integrated Risk Management for the Protection of the Population" -- https://www.kritis.bund.de/SubSites/Kritis/DE/Aktuelles/Meldungen/191216_DIN_SPEC_IRKM.html

profile_positions.title: Project Researcher

profile_positions.description:
Co-supervised bachelor theses on subjects related to Applied Geoinformatics for Civil Protection, Critical Infrastructure Protection and Resilience, Vulnerability and Criticality Assessments 
Examples:
- Analysis of road and rail infrastructure in the Alborz mountains, Iran, as a trigger of landslides. 
Research in the context of the road and rail infrastructural expansion from the Iranian provinces Alborz, Qazvin and Teheran.
- Development of a method for the prioritization of the initial operation of emergency drinking water springs in the city of Cologne in case of a  comprehensive and long-lasting electrical blackout
- Possibilities to secure the fuel supply of the primary security units in the case of a comprehensive, long-lasting power outage, with a focus on the planning of local distribution and establishment of supply priorities, using the example of the Rhein-Erft-Kreis; A GIS analysis for the accessibility of potential focus stations

Master Projects (extensive research on specific subjects before master thesis) of the Master Program Rescue Engineering:
- Data collection and database creation from social media data for the investigation of information density, usability and analysis in the context of civil protection/security
- Measuring the system-wide criticality of road network areas for emergency services - A GIS-based method

Master thesis example:
Technical advisory of a master thesis with GIS applications for Resilience of Electric Power Delivery    System (EPDS) in response to Natural Disaster: case study Cologne, which included empirical data    extracted from qualitative analysis (interviews with different stakeholders).
profile_positions.title: Co-supervisor

profile_positions.description: I identified gaps and suggested Master's coursework focus on complex and interconnected issues related to resilience and vulnerability of critical infrastructure during emergencies: 1. Simulation of the impact of targeted terrorist attacks on the power grid in Cologne 2.Communication during the failure of electricity, telephone, mobile telephony, and the internet in urban areas. 3. The potential and role of social media in crisis management 4.Networking between emergency services and transportation concerning heavy rainfall, using Cologne as an example 5.Interdependencies between temperature (dependence on heat/cold) and electrical grid 6. Investigation of external influencing factors like construction sites, traffic density, public protest situations, and weather conditions on the critical infrastructure "road," concerning the achievement of response times by the professional fire department of Frankfurt am Main 7. Vulnerability of critical infrastructures to heavy rainfall with overloading of the sewer system 8. Networking road traffic with medical care - Compliance with response times on the Cologne motorway ring by the city of Cologne's fire department 9. Interdependency analysis between the energy sector and rail traffic in Germany - Identification of important processes and elements of power supply in rail traffic in Germany and interdependence analysis 10. Resilience of vital medical devices during a multi-day, widespread power outage around Cologne 11. Fuel supply case analysis Cologne-Exploration: Temporal possibilities and limitations for evacuating a large city like Cologne following a disaster event - a GIS analysis incorporating all transportation infrastructures 12. Resilience of the public communication system against power failure 13. Networking KRITIS (Critical Infrastructure) in refugee camps: Identification and criticality analysis 14. Effects of a power outage on the operational capability of the Volunteer Fire Department in Lohmar.
profile_positions.title: Co-lecturer of the Master Course "Αnalysis of Interdependencies of Critical Infrastructures"

profile_positions.description:
Advanced an international Project as follows:
- analysed Automatic Identification System (AIS) vessel-tracking data received from a Canadian company
- developed an ArcGIS tool using the Python language via the software Eclipse for cleaning and selection of AIS data for interoperability purposes and qualitative analysis
- semi-automated vessel-tracking data visualisation developing an ArcGIS tool
- analysed patterns of mobility, routes, tracks with GIS
- developed novel interdisciplinary approaches for the identification of spoofings or rough tracks close to the coastline indicating potential illegal vessel activities
- recommended further research and applications through technical and scientific report writing with suggestions regarding improvements of the developed workflow
profile_positions.title: Project Researcher

profile_positions.description:
- 3-year involvement and management of the project “Sensor and Map Assistance for Search and 
  Rescue Teams”
- Advanced my skills on Particle Filtering for target tracking
- Applied tracking procedures to marine and terrestrial environments and visualised them with Geographic Information Systems (GIS)
- Proposed novel combinatory approaches that combined Applied Geoinformatics and Particle Filtering for ground and maritime surveillance, which led to 3 publications and the expansion of my professional network through participation in international conferences and workshops
